key_title: Key to the species of Platylobium

source.author: Ross, J.H.
source.title: Platylobium
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Ross, J.H. (1996). Platylobium. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Calyx glabrous externally except for a conspicuous fringe of hairs on the margins of the lobes
Calyx clothed throughout externally with spreading or appressed hairs
Flowers and pods subsessile, the pedicel concealed by a series of conspicuous brown papery bracts and scales
Flowers and pods distinctly pedicellate, the pedicels exceeding and exserted from the bracts and scales
Leaves broadly triangular or cordate-hastate, the lateral lobes and apex usually pungent
Leaves narrowly ovate to broadly ovate-cordate, the apex pungent or apiculate but the lateral lobes usually rounded or obtuse and not pungent
Leaves apparently simple (articulation of petiole-petiolule obscure), subsessile; leaf lamina lanceolate to narrowly elliptic, rarely cordate
Leaves unifoliolate (articulation of petiole-petiolule usually clearly demarcated by a bend or ridge), subsessile to petiolate; leaf lamina broadly ovate to orbicular or ovate, usually cordate
Bracteoles convex throughout, not reflexed (or slightly reflexed at tip only), smooth or slightly striate, brown to reddish-brown
Bracteoles nearly flat in distal half, mostly becoming recurved, orange-brown, markedly striate
Weakly erect shrubs; petioles 1–3(–8) mm long; generally fertile
Plants prostrate, often rooting at nodes; petioles 5–20 mm long; generally infertile
